You're not.
Maybe I am the seeing-illusions type.
All right! Then call! At least, call!
I've only been here five. Right now it feels like ten, but...

This is Lila Crane, from Phoenix. She's been here for a few days, looking for her sister. There's a private detective helping... and, well, we got a call tonight, from this detective, saying he'd traced Mary...
Yes.
I don't know where to start...  Except at the beginning.
No, thank you. It's my problem, too.
No. I'm just procrastinating.  People hate when the doorbell rings in the middle of the night.  Come on.
Does that mean we can't...
Nothing.  Just... all the lights out... must be asleep.
Well?
Our Deputy sleeps.
He's the Deputy Sheriff around here.
Who's he?
Let's go see Al Chambers.
Yes. I think he would have.
Sam, he called me when he had nothing definite, nothing but a dissatisfied feeling. Don't you think he'd have called if he had anything...
In a hurry.
Without calling me?
Maybe he got some definite lead. Maybe he went right on...
Where could he have gone?
No Arbogast. No Bates. And only the old lady at home...  A sick old lady unable to answer the door... or unwilling.
Sam.
He didn't come back here?
Contemplate your... panic button.
Just wait here?
I don't know...  One of us has to be here in case Arbogast's on the way.
Why can't I go out there with you?
Stay here.
You'll never find it.
Sam, I'm going.
Probably on his way back right now.
And maybe pass Arbogast on the road?  Thanks.
Sam! Why call when we can go?
Got the number of the motel out on the old highway? Bates, I think.
An hour! Or less!
Arbogast said...
Patience doesn't run in our family. Sam, I'm going out there!
That wouldn't be a wise thing to do.
Yes.
You want to run out there, bust in on Arbogast and the sick old lady, shake her up and maybe spoil everything Arbogast's been building for the last three hours.
Where's the old highway?
I feel better when you feel better.
Whenever I start contemplating the panic button, your back straightens up and your eyes get that God-looks- out-for-everybody look and... I feel better.
Hundreds! Which one is your pet?
You have an awfully nice habit, Sam.
He'll be back. Let's sit still and hang on, okay?
Are we just going to go on sitting here?
It's been three.
Sam. He said an hour. Or less.
Sometimes Saturday night has a lonely sound. Ever notice, Lila?
First rate hotel, fifty yards up the street. Come on.  After we check you in we'll go to the drugstore and get you a sandwich. Then we'll come back here... and wait.
Where... can I stay?
She'll need both of us.
You want me to stay here?
I think she'll contact me if she contacts anybody. Why don't you stay here. When she shows up... or calls... be here.
I came flying up here expecting to get some explanation... for all I know, she may be trying to get in touch with me, at home. I'd better go home.
Maybe we can handle it together.
No. I just think... anything can be explained. But Mary, doing a thing like this... I don't know how to handle...
You've led a charmed life.
I need to... I need to believe something. This is the first time I've ever come up against anything I couldn't... understand.
I didn't see her... and I didn't hear from her! Believe that!
She haven't even called you?

How could I go away? I'm in debt up to my...  If she did steal that money...  It's hard to believe she did because it's hard to see why she would. Unless she had some wild idea that it would help me... us...
Why not? Sam, is she hiding here? Are you two planning to go away with the money?
No.
I ought to call the police right now!
He must have had a darn good reason for wanting them kept out of it... All that cash...
No. The man whose money she... he talked so loud and fast, and I... I should've called the police.
It was her boss' idea not to report it to the police?
I just listened... and believed everything they told me. 'She stole the money.' 'We don't want to get her in trouble.' 'No don't bring the police in'...
You might have doubted for say five minutes or so, Sister.
Yes... I just... did. The moment they told me...
Never mind my ego. Let's talk about Mary.
Not that kind...  You men and your egos.
Well why didn't she come to me... call me...?
Yes.
Is Mary... in trouble?
I hate tears.
What thing could we be in together?
Huh?
What thing?

Look, if you two are in this thing together, I don't care, it's none of my business... But I want to see Mary. I want her to tell me she's all right and it's none of my business. Then I'll go back to Phoenix and...
Nothing! You're putting me on the defensive.
What do you know about it?
I was getting to that!
Mr. Loomis, you're so busy being defensive that you haven't even reacted to the most serious fact of all. Mary is missing.
Well what do you think, we eloped or something? Or we're living in sin and...
A good reason, I suppose.
And you thought she'd come up here, to me? If she had, what reason would she have for not calling you?
Last Friday. She left work, and home... I was in Tucson over the weekend... I haven't heard from her, not even a phone call.
No. I take it you don't either?  How long?
To begin with, where Mary is. Do you?
What should I know?
Don't you know?
What's the matter?
I don't know where. In your store, somewhere in your town... anywhere.
Where?
With you.
Here?
I want to know if my sister is here.
Is something wrong?
Is Mary here?
Lila.
I'm Mary's sister.
Sure...
May I talk to you?
Yes?
I'm late... and you have to put your shoes on.
Hey, we can leave together can't we?
Don't miss your plane.
How can you even think a thing like that!
I'm thinking of it.

You know what I'd like? A clear, empty sky... and a plane, and us in it... and somewhere a private island for sale, where we can run around without our... shoes on.  And the wherewithal to buy what I'd like.  Mary, you want to cut this off, go out and find yourself someone available.
I'll lick the stamps.
And live with me in a storeroom behind a hardware store in Fairvale. We'll have a lot of laughs. When I send my ex-wife her money, you can lick the stamps.
Sam, let's go get married.
Yeah, but when you do... you'll swing.
I haven't even been married once yet!
A couple of years and the debts will be paid off. And if she ever re- marries, the alimony stops... and then...
I pay, too. They also pay who meet in hotel rooms.

I'm fed up with sweating for people who aren't there. I sweat to pay off my father's debts... and he's in his grave... I sweat to pay my ex-wife alimony, and she's living on the other side of the world somewhere.
I'm all for it! It requires patience and temperance and a lot of sweating- out... otherwise, though, it's only hard work.  But if I can see you, touch you even as simply as this... I won't mind.
You make respectability sound... disrespectful.
Mary, whenever it's possible, tax- deductible or not, I want to see deductible you. And under any conditions.  Even respectability.
All right.
Sam! No!
And after the steak... do we send Sister to the movies and turn Mama's picture to the wall?
We can see each other, we can even have dinner... but respectably, in my house with my mother's picture on the mantel and my sister helping me broil a big steak for three!
Not even just to see you, to have lunch... in public?
No.
I can come down next week.
I have to go, Sam.
I wish I were. Not an active criminal but... a nice guy with the conscience of a criminal.  Next best thing to no conscience at all.
You couldn't be a criminal if you committed a major crime.
And besides, when you say I make tax- deductible excuses you make me out a criminal.
Sure. It's like laughing through a broken jaw, but...
Can you?
You can't laugh at it, huh?
It is tragic! Or it will be... if we go on meeting in shabby hotels whenever you can find a tax-deductible excuse for flying down deductible here...
And I'm a working man! We're a regular working-class tragedy!
I haven't time to argue. I'm a working girl.
Okay. What do we do instead, write each other lurid love letters?
This! Meeting you in secret so we can be... secretive! You come down here on business trips and we steal lunch hours and... I wish you wouldn't even come.
For what?
Sam. This is the last time.
The only girlish thing you have lost.
I've lost my girlish laughter.
I'm sorry, Mary.  My old Dad used to say 'when you can't change a situation, laugh at it.' Nothing ridicules a thing like laughing at it.
Sam!
You sure talk like a girl who's been married.
When you're married you can do a lot of things deliberately.
I've heard of married couples who deliberately spend occasional nights in cheap hotels. They say it...
Checking out time is three P.M. Hotels of this sort aren't interested in you when you come in, but when your time's up...  Sam, I hate having to be with you in a place like this.
We could laze around here a while longer.
What do I do with my free afternoon, walk you to the airport?
Call your boss and tell him you're taking the rest of the afternoon off. It's Friday anyway... and hot.
Good night.
That's it.
Crane.
Alright, Miss...
Very early. Dawn.
Alright. I'll see you in the morning. I'll bring you breakfast.  What time will you...
I'd like to, but...
Why don't you stay a little while, just for talking.
I stepped into a private trap back there -- and I want to go back and... try to pull myself out.  Before it's too late for me, too.
Phoenix?
I'm very tired. And I'll have a long drive tomorrow. All the way back to Phoenix.
You're not going to... to your room already?
Norman.
Thank you, Norman.
Yes, and just one time can be enough.  Thank you.

I've suggested it myself. But I hate to even think such a thing.  She needs me... and it isn't...  ...it isn't as if she were a maniac, a raving thing... it's just that... sometimes she goes a little mad. We all go a little mad sometimes. Haven't you?
Well? You meant well?  People always mean well, they cluck their thick tongues and shake their heads and suggest so very delicately that...
I am sorry. I only felt... it seemed she was harming you. I meant...

What do you mean about caring?  Have you ever seen one of those places? Inside? Laughing and tears and cruel eyes studying you... and my mother there?  Why? has she harmed you? She's as harmless as... one of these stuffed birds.
I'm sorry... I didn't mean it to sound uncaring...
An Institution? A madhouse?  People always call a madhouse "someplace."  Put her in Someplace!
Wouldn't it be better if you put her in... someplace...

It's too late for me. And besides... who'd look after her? She'd be alone up there, the fire would go out... damp and cold, like a grave. When you love someone, you don't do that to them, even if you hate them. Oh, I don't hate her.  I hate... what she's become. I hate... the illness.
No, not like me.
To a private island, like you?
Why don't you go away?
A son is a poor substitute for a lover.
Except you.

I mean... ill.  She had to raise me all by herself after my dad died... I was only five... and it must have been a strain. Oh, she didn't have to go out to work or anything, Dad left us with a little something... anyway, a few years ago... Mother met a man. He talked her into building this motel... We could have talked her into anything... and when.  Well... It was just too much for her when he died, too... And the way he died... Oh, it's nothing to talk about when you're eating.  Anyway, it was too much of a loss for my mother... she had nothing left.
She sounded strong...
Sometimes when she talks that way to me I'd like to... curse her out and leave her forever!  Or at least, defy her.  But I couldn't. She's ill.
If anyone ever spoke to me, the way I heard... The way she spoke to you, I don't think I could ever laugh again.
Oh I do... but I say I don't.
You should... mind it.
I was born in mine. I don't mind it anymore.
Sometimes we deliberately step into those traps.

No. People never run away from anything.  The rain didn't last very long.  You know what I think? I think we're all in our private traps, clamped in them, and none of us can ever climb out. We scratch and claw... but only at the air, only at each other, and for all of it, we never budge an inch.
Why do you ask that?
What are you running away from?
I'm looking for a private island.
Where are you going? I don't mean to pry...
Only my share.
Friends? Who needs friends.  A boy's best friend is his mother.  You've never had an empty moment in your whole life. Have you?
You go out... with friends?
Oh, no!  I run the office, tend the cabins and grounds, do little chores for mother... the ones she allows I might be capable of doing.
Is your time so empty?
It's more than a hobby... sometimes... a hobby is supposed to pass the time, not fill it.
A man should have a hobby.
It's not as expensive as you'd think. Cheap, really. Needles, thread, sawdust .. the chemicals are all that cost anything.
I imagine so.
Uncommon, too.
It's a strange hobby. Curious, I mean.

Not really. I hear that expression, that one eats "like a bird," is really a falsie, I mean a falsity, because birds eat a tremendous lot.  Oh, I don't know anything about birds. My hobby is stuffing things... taxidermy. And I guess I'd just rather stuff birds because...  well, I hate the look of beasts when they're stuffed, foxes and chimps and all... some people even stuff dogs and cats... but I can't... I think only birds look well stuffed because they're rather...  passive, to begin with... most of them...
You'd know, of course.
You eat like a bird.
It's all for you. I'm not hungry. Please go ahead.
You're very... kind.
Don't worry about it.  But as long as you've made us supper, we may as well eat it. Huh?
I'm sorry. I wish... people could apologize for other people.
You shouldn't have bothered. I really don't have that much of an appetite.
Mother...  ...what is the phrase... "she isn't herself today"... I think that's it.
I've caused you some trouble.
All right, you get your dresses hanging out and... change those wet shoes, and I'll come for you soon as it's ready...  ...with my trusty umbrella.
I'd like to.

Then will you do me a favor?  Will you have supper here?  I was just about to, myself... nothing more than some sandwiches and a lot of milk, but I'd like it if you'd come up to the house and... I don't set a fancy table but... the kitchen's awful homey.
No.
You're not going to go out again and drive up to that diner, are you?
Thank you. Again.
There's no name for it... But it's something that, that puts a person at ease.
I have?
You have something most girls never have.
Norman Bates.
Thank you, Mr. Bates.
I'll be in the office if you want anything... just tap on the wall.
The bathroom.

Stuffy in here.  Well... the mattress is soft and there're hangers in the closet and... stationary with "Bates' Motel" printed on it in case you want to make your friends back home envious... and... the... over there....
Fifteen miles. I'll get your bags.
Am I that close to Fairvale?
There's a big diner about ten miles on up... just outside Fairvale.
I want sleep more than anything. Except maybe, food.
Los Angeles.
Your home address. Oh, just the town will do.
I knew you must have. No one stops here anymore unless they do.
I thought I'd gotten off the main...
We have twelve vacancies. Twelve cabins, twelve vacancies.  They moved away the highway.
You have a vacancy?
Dirty night.
Please.
Why?
May I see your license?
Now what?
Wait a minute!
No need to apologize...
I'm sorry.

In the course of my duty, I never "take up" anyone's time, whether it's to give a warning, or a ticket, or help! Believe that, M'am.  Now if you woke up on the wrong side of... the car seat, that's one thing. But when you act as if I've just placed you under arrest...
Now wait just a moment! Turn your motor off, please.
Is there what?  I've told you there's nothing wrong... except that I'm in a hurry and you're taking up my time...
Is there?
Please... I'd like to go...
Frankly, yes.
Of course not! Am I acting as if... something's wrong?
Is anything wrong?
Then I'm free to go...?
No, m'am.
I didn't intend to sleep all night! I just pulled over... have I broken any laws?
There are plenty of motels in this area. You should have... I mean, just to be safe...
Yes. As I said, I couldn't keep my eyes...
You slept here all night?
Yes.  I didn't mean to sleep so long. I was afraid I'd have an accident last night, from sleepiness... so I decided to pull over...
In quite a hurry.
He's already been.
We thought, if you didn't mind, we'd go out to the motel with you.
I'd know the difference between Mary and an old woman.
Maybe you saw Mary!
You mean that old woman I saw sittin' in the window wasn't Norman Bates' mother?
No. An old woman, his mother.  That was early this evening. And we haven't seen or heard from him since. I went out to the motel, just got back. No one was in the office, and...
Norman took a wife?
He traced her there and called us to say he was going to question Mrs. Bates...
Bates' Motel.  He has a mind like a mechanical brain and the more information you feed it... Go on, Sam.
Yes. He traced her to that motel, out on the old highway...
Mary is Lila's sister?
Let's go out back and have some coca while the men are talking.
We have a problem.
You didn't!  It's tinkerbell.  Al wants to be sure he'll hear it if anyone rings it in the middle of the night.  Well come on in, at least!
Sorry, Mrs. Chambers. I hate bothering you...
Oh?
Have you two had breakfast?
Went out before service.
Norman found them dead together.  In bed.

It ain't only local history, Sam, it's the only murder-and-suicide case in Fairvale ledgers! Mrs. Bates poisoned this guy she was... involved with, when she found out he was married, then took a helping of the same stuff herself.  Strychnine. Ugly way to die.
I helped Norman pick out the dress she was buried in. Periwinkle blue.
He told you he wasn't coming right back cause he wanted to question Norman Bates' mother, right?
Barefaced.

Arbogast.  And after he left?  No, it's okay, Norman. How's it been going out there?  Well, I think you oughta unload that place and open up closer in to the action, a smaller place, you know... but...
Arbogast.

Norman? Sheriff Chambers.  Been just fine, thanks. Listen, we got some worries here. Did you have a man stop out there tonight...  Well, this one wouldn't be a customer, anyway. A private detective, name of...
You must remember that bad business out there. About ten years ago...
Recluse. Kinder word.
At this hour?
Why don't you call Norman and let him say just what happened, if he give the man a hot lead and he did just scooted off... it'll make the girl feel better, Albert.
Leave me alone!
...Forty thousand dollars!
Leave me alone!
Where will you get the money to do that, Bates... or do you already have it... socked away... a lot of it...
Shut up!
Buy a new one! In a new town! Where you won't have to hide your mother!
Do what?
I've been talking about your mother... about your motel. How are you going to do it?
I don't know what you've been saying.
You look frightened. Have I been saying something frightening?
I didn't think so.
My mother is not dead!
And now that your mother's dead?
This place! This isn't 'a place.' It's my only world. I grew up in that house back there. I was a happy child. My mother and I... we were more than happy.
I'm not saying you shouldn't be contented here, I'm just doubting that you are. I think if you saw a chance to get out from under... you'd unload this place...
Just an expression...  What I meant was... I'd do just about anything... to get away.  Wouldn't you?
That would be a rather extreme reaction, wouldn't it?

I always thought it was the people who are alone so much who do all the talking when they get the chance. Yet there you are, doing all the listening!  You are alone here, aren't you?  It would drive me crazy.
Yes.
I've been doing all the talking so far, haven't I?
Fine.
Satisfied with your cabin?
Yes, matter of fact.  The wife's taking a nap and... I can never keep quiet enough for her... so I thought I'd look you up and... talk.
Looking for me?
I'll show you the cabin.
Haven't any.
I'll get your bags.
Uh, uh! My boss is paying for this trip... ninety percent business... and he wants practically notarized receipts. I better sign in and get a receipt.
It isn't necessary.
Better sign in first, hasn't we?
I'll take you to...
We'd hoped to make it straight to San Francisco, but we don't like the look of that sky. Looks like a bad day coming... doesn't it.
I suppose you want a cabin.
Just coming up to ring for you.
Shut up! Shut up!
Go on, go tell her she'll not be appeasing her ugly appetite with my food... or my son! Or do I have to tell her, cause you don't have the guts? Huh, boy? You have the guts, boy?
Mother, she's just a stranger!  As if men don't desire strangers, as if... oh, I refuse to speak of disgusting things because they disgust me! You understand, Boy?
Mother, she's just a stranger... hungry, and the weather's bad...
And then what? After supper, music? Whispers?
Mother, please...
I won't have you bringing strange young girls in for supper...  ...by candlelight, I suppose, in the cheap erotic fashion of young men with cheap, erotic minds!
You must've seen an illusion, Sam. Now, I know you're not the seeing- illusion type... But no woman was illusion there and I don't believe in ghosts, so there it is!
No mother.
Nothing. Here, let's clear the path.
You didn't find anything.
And you want to tell me you saw Norman Bates' mother.
Yes! In the house behind the motel. I pounded and called but she... just ignored me.
Now wait a minute, Sam. You sure you saw an old woman?
This detective was out there and Norman told him about the girl and the detective thanked him and went away.
Was that all?
He wasn't out when you were there. He just wasn't answering the door in the dead of night... like some people do. This fellow lives like a hermit...
He was out when I was there. If he's back he probably isn't even in bed yet.
Explains the private detective. He traced her to the Bates place.  What'd he exactly say when he called you?
Everyone concerned thought... if they could get her to give back the money... they could avoid involving her with the police.
From what?
Yes.
Left Phoenix under her own steam?
They thought she'd be coming to me.
What--special autopsy?
That's the one that's got the coroner doing nightwork.
Did I?
You didn't even mention the suicides. Did you notice the beaut that came in today?
Yeah, between the gangsters and the autos, we won't need another war to carry off the population.
By gosh, them stiffs are get- tin' heavier and more of 'em every day. They even got the coroner working overtime.
[Was it] "Meirschultz"?
Said "doctor"--[something]
Did she talk?
Just before she died she came to--
Never mind your theories. Was she ever conscious?
Imagine--she was alive. What a horror. Could have been buried alive. She must have run away from the morgue.
How about me getting the help. She's quiet now, isn't she?
That's what I said. Now, lis- ten to me. I want you to help me take this woman down stairs. I will give her a shot. You can take care of her till I get help.
What do you mean "our"?
Quiet, will you? This is ser- ious. Our lives are in danger.
Ha ha, <U>you</U> have been treating.
I knew there was a catch in this some place--but spill it. Quiet and dramatic. MAXWELL In the other room, I have a crazy woman that I have been treating.
No, I wouldn't be surprised at anything from you. Winningly. MAXWELL Now, honey--you are here in time to help me and you can--
Sure--I have one little job to accomplish, then we can leave together. No doubt you are surprised at this disguise.
Then you knew of the inheritance?
[Perfectly friendly, my dear.] At last, I have really a secure living for us. We can travel or anything we choose.
So--friendly or otherwise--?
Sh--sh--I want to have a few words with you quietly.
Gosh, you had me fooled.
Okay--I'll be here at eight.
That's only natural. Maxwell will be here around eight tonight.
Don't tell him. I want to be the first to bring him the news.
I am certainly glad to hear it. I know he'll be pleased.
He hardly knew of them him- self.  I believe it was his uncle in Australia.
You say a fortune. He never spoke to me of any rich relatives.
He's inherited a fortune.
Indeed, he has often told me.
It is--you know what a struggle he's had.
No, not exactly. Why the great anxiety? It must be something important.
You mean he doesn't work for you?
I understand my husband is-- your assistant. May I see him please?
Did you wish to see someone?
Take him to the psychopathic hospital.
Yes--I can't stand it-- everybody wants papers-- oh, oh
Dr. Meirschultz, too?
Papers--they all want me to sign papers.
Tell me, just what you know of Dr. Meirschultz.
Hm--pressure-- To Buckley. That's all right. We'll talk later.
No, no! I won't sign any pa- pers. You can't make me--
I don't know--I can't tell--
Why, yes, to you, Mr.--Mr. --what?
You--a friend to me?
No, I don't want money. I only want to find out who you are and where you live. My business is finding peo- ple. Not taking their money.
Maybe you want my money, too.
Who wants your money-- maybe I can help you.
No--I don't want to give any money. Everybody wants money--I'm not going to give any money.
What made you steal? Are you hungry?
I don't know, [I tell you].
Who are you? What is your name?
No-
Why didn't you notify the police?
I know I am. Why, I even heard a shot up there last night.
Maybe you're right.
It may be, but to my notion, those that monkeys with what they got no business to get queer sooner or later.
That sounds to me very remarkable.
Sure--they're sorta queer, I'd say. They's lots of queer goings on up there. They even brought a dog back to life once.
By the way--did you hear a shot last night?
Oh, him. He has a cat of his own. But his assistant--he's the cat-hatenest man I ever saw. Goofy, if ya ast me.]

You're not as quick as I thought. I figgered out that rats breed faster than cats-- cat skins make good fur-- The cats eat rats. Rats eat raw meat. That is, they eat the carcasses of the cats. So --the cats eat the rats--the rats eat the cats. And I get the skins--simple ain't it?
But where do the rats come in?
That's it. You get it quick.
Oh, I see. Cats' fur.
Oh, no. It's my own idea. I'm in the business. In the fur business.
What' s the idea [of wanting so many] do you sell them [to the doctor]?
Sure, got thousand cats, too. Look at 'em-- Points to cages of cats.
Thousands?
Yeah--thousands, and right in my back yard.
[Lot of] How many cats you have--what's the matter-- rats?
He's been stealing my cats to experiment on [them]. I know cause I've been [watching] spying on him.
I understand from your neighbors that all [them] cats are making noise at night. Dr. Meirschultz has put in a complaint.
Come on, we're wasting time.
Oh, <U>I'm</U> crazy, am I? Let me tell you something.  Those women have--the gleam--
Man, you're crazy. What kind of a place is this?
It won't do any good. They are a pair of would-be mur- deresses fighting it out.
Take me down there.
Oh, nothing. A cou- ple of my patients having a little argument.
What's that?
Oh, nothing. He is crazy, that's all. I had a little trouble with him.
Yes. Mr. Buckley thinks you treated him a little rough. He's in the hospital. How about it?
You here again?
I'd like to have a look.
Oh, just the basement. Some day I intend to build an experimental laboratory down there. It will save me from intrusion.
What's down there?
Mind if I look around? Seems to me you have car- ried on some interesting experiments. Sure of himself but taking no chances. MAXWELL Sure, I'll take you thru.
Oh no. Mostly research in endocrinology.
Do you have many patients, doctor?
Fine. Mrs. Buckley will be all right when she gets used to the idea.
Oh, yes, he's in good hands now.
Yes indeed. He has been a <U>difficult</U> case. Now that <U>you</U> have him in custody--you have him haven't you?
So--that's it. Buckley took the body.
Why, Buckley stole that body. That's what alarmed Mrs. Buckley so. I have been try- ing to get her to put Buckley in an institution but she wants to keep him.
Yeah, he was picked up-- also the body from the morgue. Say, what did you have to do with stealing that body?
Well, news of Buckley?
How do you do.
Oh, Maxwell? He's left.
By the way, where <U>is</U> your assistant?
You found Buckley?
I'm detective Jones. Just dropped in to tell you a bit of news.
Oh, so you feel that way too . Motions to other room. Stay in there--I'll call you when needed.
It sounds all right, except for the fact that she's crazy. It seems to me she has the right idea--.

[Something very important. I have been threatened;] Mrs. Maxwell, my assistant's wife, is crazy.  She thinks I mur- dered her husband. [She wants to murder me.] I want you to help me quiet her-- give her a shot from this hypo. [Keep it hid till we get her] down in the basement-- there is a secret vault [there]. We will put her there till we get your husband--[then turn her over to the authorities. Then we will both be free.]
How? What can I do?
You are right. But before I can get him back here, you will have to help me.
Not so fast, Mrs. Buckley. That was your idea!
You can't double-cross me like that.  You were to help me. You were to operate on him. You were going to put him under my power.
No, you can't do that--they'll get suspicious--
I'm going to call the police.
What are you going to do?
He isn't here.
Dr. Meirschultz, please.
Nonsense! ... It's here! ... Your blood ...
Yes!
You're losing your blood?
I'm losing my blood!
What is it now?
Go to sleep!
The wound is bleeding!
What is it?
The master ... is asleep!
Yes!
Your father?
What did it say?
That called ... commanded ...
That spoke to you?
A voice ...
What were you dreaming about?
No!  Good night!
No?
There's no child here, and no dogs either.
But ... the dogs...
There's no child here.
Yes.
The child!
Yes, the child ...
Did you hear?

The blood transfusion is completed. While Marc himself is looking after the patient, the nurse leads Nikolas into an adjoining room, where she makes him sit down and prepares his bandage. The doctor stands bending over Lone.
Another fragment of the diary is shown [having to do with vampires].

The blood transfusion continues. Marc has positioned himself outside the circle of light from the lamp, so that he can see Nikolas in bright light, while he himself sits in the dark. Nikolas watches Lone's face anxiously and closely during her struggle with death. Life slowly seems to return to her, and her breathing becomes more peaceful. She opens her eyes and looks at the people round her, but she is much too enfeebled to speak, and closes her eyes again. Marc keeps a close watch on Nikolas, who grows paler and paler. His eyes swivel slowly from Nikolas to the patient and back to Nikolas again.

Joseph is reading the diary, which arouses his interest more and more. It is as if he finds a connection between what he reads and the fearful events that have taken place around him. An extract from the diary is shown.
The blood transfusion is now in progress. The only words are curt orders like: 'Now! - Quickly! - That's enough! - Give it to me! - Sit still!' etc.

Joseph returns from the room where Gis?le is. He has evidently succeeded in calming her. He goes and sits in the chair where Nikolas sat. He rests his head in his hand. He sees the open diary and begins reading it.
By the time we return there, all the preparations for the blood transfusion are completed.
It's Igor at the Wax Museum! You'll find your judge embalmed in wax! He's a statue of Voltaire, with all the other corpses! The whole place is a morgue -- do you hear? -- a morgue!
You lie!
No -- the only thing I did for him was to keep track of the man named Worth that runs the place where you arrested me tonight.
But you were in on it -- you worked for him.
No -- I didn't. It was Igor at the waxworks.
You killed him!  Come on with the rest of it. You killed him!
Well, thank goodness, that's settled.
I think so.
Yeah, but they leave you plenty.
If you're going to be indiscreet, I wish you'd be a little more discreet about it. Rich men, like Winton, love you and leave you.
No? Give me a chance, baby. Money is music in my ears, and when his old man kicks off there'll be a million dollar tune.
You wouldn't get mixed up with that little rotter, would you?
I'm hungry. I'll eat the first child I see. And I've an appointment with young Winton at 8:30.
What's the rush? There's no first act. They'll all be there and we don't have to appear at any particular time.
Ouch! Eat? You can do a solo if you don't step on it. I'm going to bow out on you.
Why didn't you eat last night?
I can't convince the inner woman that we can wait. She's howling for a bit of ground beef before we drop in on Santa Claus and the other dummies. I've only had a cup of coffee since last night.
There's no hurry. It's early.
I'll have it for supper.  So long.
But what about lunch?
Then marry Ralph ... you'll be the happiest couple in the world.
You think money is the only requisite. It happens that the poor people are happier.
He can look like a chimpanzee and act like an igorot but he must have dough -- plenty of dough.
You would.
All right, you raise the kids -- I'll raise the roof. I'd rather die with an athletic heart from shaking cocktails and bankers, than expire in a pan of dirty dish water.
I don't agree with you.
I've been in love so many times my heart is calloused ... but I've never hit one with dough. This love-in-an-attic isn't my idea of a way to spend a pleasant afternoon.
I don't think you could have a real affair. You couldn't care for anyone.
I don't have any affairs. What do you mean?
In the can.  The hoosegow! Mrs. Winton's little boy. The Pawk Avenue Wintons, you know ... and plenty of do-re-mi.  He's in the jail-house now ...
Did you? Where?
I met one last night ... all the money this side of Peoria.
I don't see any big-moneyed boys running after you.
I just had a picture of you telling a landlady some day that you didn't have the rent, but Ralph is awful sweet.
What are you laughing at?
I wish you wouldn't be so sarcastic about Ralph. He's the sweetest kid I know.
I wondered. Did he invite you to lunch, or did you invite him?
Yes, why?
I'm glad you told me. Good night, Mr. Burton.
That's the way I feel about it.
So that's the way it is?
Well, that's just how stupid I am. When you go riding, it will be with me. And if it's with someone else, you can make it a permanent arrangement.
I'd call it stupid at any time.
You wouldn't have said that before you met her.
I'm not quarreling, only ...
Are we going to have the same quarrel over again?
Don't kid yourself -- she means it.
She thinks it's funny to talk the way she does, but--
Well, I do say it.
I won't let you say that!
What's nice about her? ... a hard-boiled little gold digger.
Nonsense. She's one of the nicest girls I know.
She isn't anybody's friend, and I don't like you living with her. She's a bad influence.
But why? She's the best friend I've got.
Delighted, I'm sure.
Why, certainly, sir. My fiance. Charlotte, may I present Mr. Igor.
Well, you see, the old chap is pretty anxious to open on schedule. All of his advertising announced the opening tonight.
Disappoint me? Why, what do you mean, dear?
And I have no desire to hurt you. You will always be beautiful. Think, my child, in a thousand years you will be as lovely as you are now.
Please, oh, please, I haven't done anything to hurt you.
Ralph! Ralph!
We have found immortality, you and I. You must not be afraid.
Let me go! Let me go!
It is no trouble at all, my child. This is the strange, vicarious pleasure that remains for me -- to see others enjoy the beauty I used to create.  My footing is not too secure.
Oh, please, Mr. Igor, I'm terribly ashamed. I shouldn't have put you to so much trouble.
I'd love to.

And he will probably demand the life of anyone who agrees with you. Let him think it was his fault ... He should be along very shortly .. . But be very stern before you forgive him, especially if it is your fault  ...  While you're waiting for your friend, would you like to see some new figures I have downstairs?
But it was really my fault.
Oh, you children, you happy children. You've quarreled and now you're going to be friends again. And that is as it should be. Never let any stupid misunderstandings come between you.
No -- I -- wanted to speak to Ralph. We had a silly argument last night and I said something unkind.
Oh! So, my little friend, you have honored me by accepting my invitation of last night.
Oh! Mr. Igor! -- I'm so glad you're here -- I don't know why I should be, but I was a little bit afraid.

They are.  My boy, I think you are right. Everyone is tired out today and now that we have seen my doors open in a new country, I am beginning to realize that I am a little tired myself. You can call that fellow in from the front. I think we'll close for the night.
But I think these things are beautiful.
At any time. You will always be welcome.
We'll be coming to the opening.
I'd love to, at any time.

Although you would be amused if I were to tell you that I knew you before you were born. Before this terrible thing happened to me ...  ... I made a very beautiful statue. Even if I had not met with this disaster, I could never have hoped to do anything finer, probably nothing quite so fine. And, my child, you are that figure come to life. I wonder, some time, would you pose for one of my sculptors who does very excellent work?
Thank you.
If you will forgive this poor, crippled stump, my dear, I am very happy to know you.
Nothing doing. This is my percentage. You birds are going to get yours. And anyhow, I found this dump.
Hey, what do you think you're doing? Put that stuff back!
I don't know what he was, but he made Frankenstein look like a lily!
You mean he was colored?

Not a very good one, I guess. He wasn't like anything human. He hobbled and swayed like a monkey, and the face, from the glimpse I got of it in the light from the street, was like an African war mask.
How quaint. But I can go any place you can.
It happens that I'm the law.
Whatever you are, you're the only one of it.
What do you think I am?
Listen, copper, get a load of this. While you're chinning yourself on a bar rail, I run down this story ... my story. Consider yourself my assistant.
Don't take my word for it. Get down there yourself and give a look.
Are you giving me this straight?
I'm not kidding. Joan Gale's body is packed in the box in the basement, and I saw the most horrible thing down there.
Hello, Express. What's the idea, trying to outsmart the police?
The body of Joan Gale!
What! What are you talking about?
I'm going to get even with you, you dirty stiff! I'll do it!
That's what I said.
Yes, you could. Cut out this rotten business and act like a lady. Marry me.
Listen, stupid, could I do anything that would possibly meet with your approval?
I'm going to make you eat dirt, you soap bubble! I'm going to make you beg for somebody to help you let go!
What goofy idea have you got now? Don't tell me you suspect Judge Ramsey of stealing the body.
Was there any art on Judge Ramsey?
Go on, little girl, take your troubles somewhere else. I don't feel like talking to you.
Say, you're always razzing everything I do, but this is one time I'm in.

What do you mean -- haywire? You start out after murderers and come back with three-for-a-dime bootleggers. You start to solve murder mysteries and break up crap games. You're grand! I'm for you! Stupendous!
This one's a story, but I'm not going to tell you what it is. Every time I tell you anything it goes haywire.
You here again like an evil spirit to mar my happiness?
Mit me, kid. I've got a classic.
Almost! I'll still bet I'm right, and let you write your own ticket.
Almost certain.
No kiddin'?
That dear, innocent Judge Ramsey that you were so sure got bumped off for knowing too much has been located in South America.
What do you mean?
Oh, by the way, another pet theory of yours just blew up.
All right, Master Mind.  But there's something cockeyed about that joint and I'm going to find out what it is.
Come down to earth. Do you think they would dare do anything like that? Don't you think they'd know that figure would be recognized? Shake your head real hard -- you'll be all right.
Let it go.
Work that up into a comic strip and syndicate it.

And it came to life and divorced you. I know all about that. Now my idea is this: Somebody swipes the girl's body, takes impression, makes a mold, produces wax figure ... Bingo! ... Peddles it to this old skate down there!
I used to be married to one.
Listen, Jo-jo. Does this mean anything to you? Joan Gale's body swiped from the morgue -- Did you ever hear of such a thing as a death mask?
About the Gale girl, I mean. Where do we go from there? What of it?
What!
We'll grant that.
Just this -- I got a look at that dump a little while ago and if they haven't got a wax figure of Joan Gale in that line-up, then I'm crazy.
No kiddin'. What's your idea?
All right, you poor baboon, you can guess the rest of it!
Well, you can't blame a guy for getting a little breathless with a scoop like that.
I asked you to keep your trap shut!
Now don't that call for an extra!
Jim, there's a little hokey-pokey wax museum opening up down on 14th Street.
All right, wise guy. Go ahead. Spill it.
Listen, Jim -- and if you wisecrack while I'm talking I'll crown you with the inkwell.
Well, no one would ever suspect it. You don't sound right.
I am right! I know I'm right!
So you can give me an argument and tell me I'm wrong. Don't be sil, Kid.
Well, why so mysterious! Come on, spill it.
Hey, Mattie, dig into the morgue and send up all the art you have on Joan Gale.
I want to see the original pictures of Joan Gale.
Come in, Prussic Acid. What's on your mind?
Get out of here.
Which one is me? The horse?
Sleep on it ... we'll get it tomorrow.
No, there's another point I want to iron out.
Great! ... If he's worthless we'll give him away as a bridge prize. Come on -- beat it. It's five o'clock. You need some sleep.
On the square, Jimmy, if you'd seen Winton down there -- I'm not holding a brief for him -- maybe he's a dirty pup, but he's scared and hysterical -- and so kinda dumb and worthless ...
Nope, I'm through!
Hey, come here, Sob-sister!
All right, you said I was fired. Well, I quit! Give the assignment to somebody else.
You cannot. I'm still editor of this sheet.
Well, that's got nothing to do with this case. Can I handle this my way?
Whooey -- he took a run-out powder.
Or was bumped off by someone who was afraid of him.
Except that he disappeared when things got too hot.
And they never proved anything against him.
Oh, you won't -- you were pretty tough about Judge Ramsey -- a little while ago --
Well, I won't work on it from that angle.

You don't think he'd be sap enough to do the job himself. I hope they give him the works. Even if he didn't kill the kid, he's responsible for her death, and they can fry him any time without making me sore.
Well, anyway, he couldn't have copped that body -- he was in jail.

I'm glad to hear it. When did you go in for crusading in the cause of justice? This lousy mug, with all the money in the world, has had two or three nasty affairs. He's kept out o' print because his great- grandfather was smarter than the Indians.
You give me a pain!
He's getting a break, ain't he? He's front page.
No, I mean it. I think this kid's entitled to a break.
And ruin a perfectly good story? Don't be silly.

I wouldn't be trying, beloved. I would hang him! And another thing, all this gaga about the body disappearing. Eight bodies have been stolen in New York within the last eighteen months. Doesn't it seem more reasonable to hook this up from that angle?
Why the goose pimples? If he wasn't social register -- if it was somebody like me, you'd be trying to hang him.
If this kid was some unknown soda jerker, they wouldn't have pinched him. But he's George Winton and they're playing him up. It's a Roman holiday for every paper hat editor in New York.
Well, ain't that a shame. Nice little chappie that wouldn't harm a fly ... everybody picking on the little fellow.
Quick, Watson, the cookbook!
That is none of our business.  But you bring me something for the next edition if it's only a recipe for spaghetti!
And how does one go about getting these human documents, may I inquire?
Well, is it my fault if nothing happens?
All right, what about it? We get out a paper just the same. Did you ever stop to think of that?
What do you mean, you poor ham! This is New Year's!
I'm through clowning. You're all washed up. Get out!
That you're a sure bet to place in the bread line. There's no room on this rag for the purely ornamental. You're easy on the eyes and pretty conceited about it.
Meaning what?
Great. Consider yourself crippled -- financially. See if you can jar your charming friends loose from enough to eat on.
Charming. More delightful people crippled.
Yeah.  Have a pleasant vacation?
Where did you get the news item?  From a little bird?
Been doing experiments with Scotch and soda again?
As I live and breathe and wear spats ... the prince.
Well, maybe it was. I don't remember.  You got to do something for me, I can't stand it any longer -- I can't!
You used to go to Worth's place a whole lot. What makes you sure it wasn't there?
No, sir, I'm sure it wasn't there.
You didn't happen to be going to Worth's place, did you?
No, sir. About three months ago.
Don't remember what day that was, do you?
I don't remember. Not so very far--
Where were you going when you got in that cab?
Yes, sir. I got in the cab and it was layin' there on the floor.
Thanks.
It's all yours.
Don't give this to anybody else, will you?
There's an autopsy ordered at Bellevue immediately. You better skip over there.
Make it snappy, Colonel.
Hotcha! Saved, one job!
Nothing. Only she may have tried to blackmail him. You know such things have happened. Anyway, he was at her apartment a few hours before she was found dead.
What does that prove?
Why would I string y'? They were sweeties until a month ago.
Say, if you're stringin' me, Old-Timer ...
Don't they? He's down at The Tombs right now.
They don't suspect him?
That's the one.
Old Howard Winton's cub?
Do you know George Winton?
No foolin' -- any suspect?
Oh, yeah? Maybe she didn't commit suicide. She may have been murdered!
Yes, she committed suicide yesterday. That's not news. I heard about it last year.
I've got a story for you. You know the Joan Gale girl?
I've got to make news, if I have to bite a dog.  Hey, Kelly! Oh, mi gosh, even he walked out on me.
No kiddin'.
I'm people which the old year saw out. I'm canned, fired!
Fine. You're the first reporter in here for two hours. You people seeing the old year out?
How's every little thing?
Call the Homicide Squad!
Here's a wow.
Stories scarcer than caviar at a street cleaner's banquet, and he says, bring me a yarn. All I have to do is get a story.
I told you he was a sore.
Ain't that something. The mad monk of Manhattan. Here goes nothing.  Listen to the animal cracker roar like a lion.
Listen, Flo, cut it out. Hard-Tack is pretty sore.
Plain-clothes man.  Come on, slaves, drink and be merry for tomorrow you might be appointed correspondent to Washington ... a fate worse than death.
What do you mean police dog?
He's not a stag hound. His name is Kelly and he's a police dog.
Where'd you get the stag hound?
Better cut that out.  That's what happens to girls who bite their nails.  What's wrong?
Ralph, come here a minute, will you?
No. I wanted to do it without saying anything. I think he's worth it.
Gee, that's great. After the bad opening that night the old boy was pretty blue. This will pep him up. Have you told him about it?

Well, I'll tell you a secret. I kinda like the old gent and I'm trying to build a special Sunday Magazine story out of him. It might help him a whole lot. But that's a side issue -- something I do on my own time.
I guess so. But wouldn't it be better for you to wait until the old man's here?
I'm after news, as usual. I wonder if it would be all right for me to slip in and look around your factory?
What are you people doing out in the middle of the night?
Horsefeathers!
Nix, Flo -- he won't let you in and you'll only get me in Dutch.
Who? Old Santa Claus there? That's easy for anyone with my sex appeal. He's a pushover. Watch me stand that old dodo on his ear.
No use. He's a crab, I tell you.
He might get some publicity out of it.
Don't worry -- she'll get used to it.
Gee, honey-bunch, I'm sorry -- I'm going to have to disappoint you.
Fine, thanks.
Don't ask any questions. Come on!
What is it? What happened?
Well, that being the case, I'll take it up with the board of directors. Hey, listen, aviator, here we are!
Heaven knows. A lot.
How much money have you got?
You don't believe me. You think I'm just talking. Will you marry me?
Oh, is that what caused it?
No, really -- I'm crazy about you.
It doesn't usually take that long, but I'll forgive you -- you were in a tough spot when I met you.
I suppose this is going to sound absurd. I've only known you twenty-four hours, but I'm in love with you.
--and so determined to live that I'm going to get out and take a taxi if you don't watch where you're going.
Darned if I don't!
You go in for dangerous things.
Why?
No -- No -- I -- I -- I don't want to see it.
There she is! You'll find Joan Gale in that box.
I told you what to do. Drive around the corner out of sight of the house. I want to get a closer look at the place.
Please. I'm sorry. I'll see it through. What do you want me to do?
All right, brother. Then you can go to some nice warm place, and I don't mean California.
I told you I didn't want to mix in it.
What! And let every rag in town grab a red-hot story? Not so you could notice it! Now, look, I want you to drive me around the corner and wait for me.
Not even then. The police are the proper people to conduct this affair. Now if you've got any suspicions I'll drive you to the nearest police station.
Not even if it gives you a clean bill of health?
Now look here. It's not up to us to do our own detective work. I've had enough trouble over this matter. I don't want anything more to do with it.
That's what they're going to ask you.
Who'd steal her body?
That happens to be the truth.
Then why are you telling me a crazy lie? ...
Hold on, hold on. I'm trying to help you, if you're on the square, and I think you are.
Stolen! What are you trying to do to me? ... You're working with the police! ... You're trying to make me say something that can be used against me! You're trying ...
Well, let's get back to the case in hand. They ordered an autopsy and discovered her body had been stolen from the morgue.
No.  Why didn't I take her out somewhere? But she was laughing and seemed so happy.
You weren't going with her?
We planned a trip for her. I was going to send her to Bermuda.
I see. Was that all she said?
She laughed and told me that we were being silly, that we didn't care for each other any more but we needn't hate each other ...  ... She said she wanted to be friends.
Uh-huh. Do you remember what she said? What did you talk about?
They didn't give me a chance. We had a couple of drinks and she was all right then. She seemed happy.
Hmmm. Why didn't you tell that to the police?
For a few minutes the afternoon before -- before --
Your dad has stood for plenty. Now let's get down to cases. When did you see the Dale girl last?
My lawyers will be on the job in a little while, and I warn you people anything you print about me you've got to prove. Dad won't stand for--
That's what I said.
Cry-baby?
Listen, kid. You're in a tough spot, and you can make it a whole lot easier for yourself if you cut out the cry-baby stuff --

Yes, sure, that's fine. While I'm proving my innocence, you people are going to uncover every petty kid trick I ever did ... you're going to write editorials about every cocktail I ever drank. Anything that any sane, normal person might have done will have a sinister meaning, if I did it.  Go on! Get out! I don't want to talk to you!
Come on, old man, that won't do. You know you're innocent until proven guilty.
Yeah. I suppose you people will crucify me for something I didn't do.  I didn't! You understand that! ... I didn't do it! She -- tried before --
Good night.  And I am very grateful to you.
Good night, sir.
It will always afford me great pleasure to see you.
I regret I can't spend the time I'd like with your exhibition, but I'm going to worry the life out of you when I come back.
You will have won the undying gratitude of us all.  Is that not so, Marie Antoinette?
She will undoubtedly keep her promise. If you'll grant me the privilege, I'd like to submit this work to the Royal Academy when I get back.

My partner believes that I should build a horror chamber, immortalizing the hideous crimes and criminals of London. At such times Marie Antoinette has reassured me, she has promised me recognition for the devotion I gave to her.
Even those delicate veins, the texture of this flesh -- I have never seen anything more exquisite.
You are too gracious. These things have some merit, I suspect ... but this--  ... I am convinced, is fine.
Not at all -- let me show you how easily it can be done.
You're insane.
Well, what do you think I'm in this for?  Think of it, man, a match -- a cigar stub -- and ten thousand pounds to divide between us!
And they are welcome to them. To perpetuate such creatures is to celebrate their crimes.

You've got to permit it! Whose fault is it that no one comes here? The museum at Walston Lane does well enough, and why? They've got Jack the Ripper, Burke and Hare, the Mad Butcher, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street and things people pay to see.
And you think I will permit this, my friend?
I'm not asking you anything. I'm telling you what I'm going to do!
You are asking to burn these people ... you are asking? ...
I want the money back I've thrown into this rubbish heap.
A fire! Is this your idea of humor, my friend?
Yes, there's our way out. A fire in this place would give us ten thousand pounds.
Fire insurance!
No -- I'm lying to amuse myself!  Now look here, I've an idea that will get us out of all this. We haven't twopence between us, but we've got these.
Is that a fact?
Something important has got to come of it! Do you know that the rent on this place isn't paid?
Your money may have been well invested, my friend. Something important may come of all this.
That is unfortunate.
I came back for some of the books. I am trying to straighten out the accounts. I don't hope to impress you, but I may as well tell you: We haven't a farthing!
Quite so. Quite so.  And you, my little friend, my little Marie Antoinette. It is kind of you to be present.

I wouldn't feel too disappointed at the slimness of your audience tonight, Mr. Igor. The weather was against you, and the people are tired and getting over their celebration and preparing to go to work tomorrow.
All right, I'll tell them. They're right here in front.
If you leave before the work is done, you will be gone for a much longer period ... you will be gone for good.
I will only be gone about half an hour.
That is unfortunate. They will have to wait.
But I have some friends waiting.
To lunch, you say. I am having coffee and sandwiches sent in. We are not leaving until we have everything ready for the opening.
To lunch.
If it is freedom to represent people with limbs that don't match -- cripples -- you have achieved your purpose. Anatomy! Heaven forgive you. You must have studied with a sideshow of freaks!
But the composition as a whole -- I've tried to keep a sketchy freedom.
Everything, my friend. And you hope to be a great sculptor --  A great sculptor. Look -- this forearm is at least two inches too long.
That doesn't seem so bad to me. What is wrong with it?
And he isn't struck dead! This man, he lives! It would be interesting to know, young man, where and when you studied anatomy.
One of the maids-in-waiting for that Elizabethan group.
If my curiosity is not too great, would you mind telling me what manner of animal this is you are designing?
Don't lose sight of him. This is the most important thing in my life.
I'd know him anywhere.
He can't hear you.
What are you laughing at?
I wonder if I could have her pose for me.
She is the soul of that statue.
You have done well, and now I, too, have something for you. Come.
I'd be glad to, Mr. Igor.  I think I'll have somethin' to tell you soon.
Yes.
Shall we unpack it?

With the intelligence of a human being, the speed of a greyhound, and the strength of a grizzly bear.

All right, assuming the program is accurate, this is a description of the animal with that claw.  "Species unidentified.  Genus: unidentified.  Phylum unknown.  Male, weight in excess of 240 kg.  Brain capacity, 900 centimeters." That means it's highly intelligent. "Quadrupedal."

But a virus normally codes for other viruses.  This one's making human and animal proteins.  Listen to this.  "Glycotetraglycine collagenoid. Weinstein's tropic hormone.  4- monoxytocin supressin hormone."
That's not so unusual.  Many plants carry viruses.  Like the burls on Maple trees.

Several problems with that theory. For one thing, this egg is intact. For another, according to Pendergast, the crates were shipped here on a boat.  Everyone on board was killed like Beauregard.  If the thing hatched in mid-ocean, where did it go?

Come on, Margo.  We're on the verge of something huge.  Let's consider the possibility, just the three of us, alone in this room.  What if John was right.  I mean, what if?  And he sent back an egg of his monster in the crates.  When it got to the museum, it hatched.

Cuthbert's counting on the exhibition's success.  The museum is in debt.  Contributions and public funding have dried up.  Admissions no longer cover overhead.  The last big infusion of cash we had was the King Tut exhibit.  Cuthbert was hired to get us out of the red.  If the Superstition Exhibit isn't lucrative, he'll have to start auctioning off some of these gems.
